posts.title: Socrate
posts.excerpt: ‘Socrates’ Mirrors the Platonic Touch of RosselliniSomething more than wordplay is involved when one describes Roberto Rossellini’s “Socrates,” which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, as the great Italian director’s most Socratic film, in his most Platonic style. posts._title: Cy Endfield – Try and Get Me AKA The Sound of Fury (1950)
posts.title: Try and Get Me
posts.excerpt: Todd Wiener writes:In 1947, novelist and B-movie screenwriter Jo Pagano published his third novel titled The Condemned. The novel was based upon the 1933 kidnapping and murder of Brooke Hart in San Jose, California, and the subsequent lynching of two suspects by a hysterical mob fueled by a frenzied media. Considered the only public lynching …

posts.title: The Bat
posts.excerpt: Synopsis:Mystery writer Cornelia Van Gorder has rented a country house called “The Oaks”, which not long ago had been the scene of some murders committed by a strange and violent criminal known as “The Bat”. posts._title: Robert Dornhelm & Earle Mack – The Children of Theatre Street (1977)
posts.title: The Children of Theatre Street
posts.excerpt: This documentary provides a fascinating look at one of the world’s greatest schools of dance, the Kirov School in Leningrad, where renowned dancers such as Nijinsky, Karsavina, Anna Pavlova, Nureyev, Baryshnikov and Makarova have studied. This documentary provides a close-up look at the regimen these dedicated young dancers must follow in order to fulfill their …

posts.title: The Horse Soldiers
posts.excerpt: Ex railroad man, Yankee Colonel John Marlowe leads an irregular troop on a mission into the Confederacy, feuding every step of the way with his company doctor Major Kendall. posts.title: Pause
posts.excerpt: Quote:Elpida, a middle-aged housewife, is trapped in the misery of an oppressive loveless marriage, with a man who has no consideration for her feelings and needs. posts.title: Hebi no michi
posts.excerpt: Midnight Eye review:Serpent’s Path and its companion piece Eyes of the Spider (Kumo No Hitomi) both start from the same premise: a man taking revenge for the murder of a child.
